summary: This document is an email chain from November 2007 between defense attorney Jay Lefkowitz and a federal prosecutor (USAFLS) regarding the Jeffrey Epstein plea agreement. The exchange focuses on disputes over the selection of attorneys Podhurst and Josephsberg to administer victim compensation, and strong objections from Epstein's defense team to the government's plan to notify alleged victims of their civil rights under the agreement. It reveals tensions over the interpretation of the Non-Prosecution Agreement and victim notification procedures.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein, corresponding with federal prosecutors to object to victim notification letters and discuss the selection of attorneys Podhurst and Josephsberg.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The client of Jay Lefkowitz, subject of the Non-Prosecution Agreement and upcoming plea deal.

persons.name: Judge Davis
persons.context: Selected attorneys Aaron Podhurst and Bob Josephsberg for an assignment related to the Epstein agreement.

persons.name: Aaron Podhurst
persons.context: Attorney selected by Judge Davis, along with Bob Josephsberg, for an assignment related to the Epstein case; described as having a stellar reputation.

persons.name: Bob Josephsberg
persons.context: Attorney selected by Judge Davis, along with Aaron Podhurst, for an assignment related to the Epstein case; known to Professor Dershowitz from law school.

persons.name: Professor Dershowitz
persons.context: Member of Epstein's defense team who appeared comfortable with the selection of Podhurst and Josephsberg and knew Josephsberg from law school.

persons.name: Guy Lewis
persons.context: Member of Epstein's defense team who had known for some time about Judge Davis's efforts to secure Podhurst and Josephsberg.

persons.name: Lili Ann Sanchez
persons.context: Member of Epstein's defense team familiar with Podhurst and Josephsberg.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Member of Epstein's defense team familiar with Podhurst and Josephsberg.

persons.name: Judge Starr
persons.context: Requested a meeting with Assistant Attorney General Fisher to address concerns about the section 2255 component of the Agreement.

persons.name: Assistant Attorney General Fisher
persons.context: Subject of a requested meeting by Judge Starr to discuss the section 2255 component of the Epstein agreement.

connections.description: Lefkowitz is representing Epstein in the plea agreement negotiations and corresponding with prosecutors on his behalf.
Both are part of Epstein's defense team, as referenced in the email discussing their meeting.
Dershowitz knew Josephsberg from law school, as noted in the email.
Lewis was aware of Judge Davis's efforts to secure Podhurst for the assignment, indicating prior professional knowledge.
Judge Davis selected Podhurst (and Josephsberg) for an assignment related to the Epstein agreement.

events.title: Meeting between defense and prosecution
events.description: Meeting where prosecutors informed defense attorneys of Judge Davis's selection of Podhurst and Josephsberg, and where Dershowitz and Lefkowitz appeared comfortable with the selection.

events.title: Deadline for objection to attorney selection
events.description: Prosecutor's deadline for Epstein's defense to provide good-faith objections to the selection of Podhurst and Josephsberg, after which victim notification would proceed.

events.title: Planned victim notification
events.description: Prosecutor's stated intention to notify victims by letter after close of business, pending defense objections.

events.title: Upcoming Epstein plea entry
events.description: Mention that Mr. Epstein will enter his plea in another few weeks.

events.title: Requested meeting with AAG Fisher
events.description: Judge Starr requested a meeting with Assistant Attorney General Fisher to address concerns about the section 2255 component of the Agreement, hoped to occur the following week.

keyFacts: Epstein's defense team, led by Jay Lefkowitz, strongly objected to the government sending notification letters to alleged victims about their civil rights under the plea agreement, calling it 'unprecedented' and 'incendiary.'

The defense argued that the Justice for All Act of 2004 (which mandates victim notification) applies to restitution, not the civil remedy under 18 USC ยง 2255 referenced in the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
Prosecutors insisted on a statutory obligation to notify victims in a timely fashion and set a deadline for defense objections to the court-appointed attorneys (Podhurst and Josephsberg).
The email reveals that Epstein's defense team had previously offered to establish a restitution fund for victims, but this option was rejected by the prosecution.

Tensions existed over the selection and vetting of attorneys Podhurst and Josephsberg, with the defense claiming surprise at their selection despite prosecutors stating the defense team was familiar with them.
